title-group.article-title: Precision Medicine: Long-Term Treatment with Sulfonylureas in Patients with Neonatal Diabetes Due to KCNJ11 Mutations

contrib-group.aff: 1Section of Pediatric and Adult Endocrinology, Diabetes, and Metabolism Kovler Diabetes Center, University of Chicago, 5841 S. Maryland Ave., MC1027-N235, Chicago, IL 60637, USA

fn.p: Conflict of Interest The authors declare that they have no conflict of interest.

sec.title: Purpose of Review
sec.p: The goal of this review is to provide updates on the safety and efficacy of long-term sulfonylurea use in patients with KCNJ11-related diabetes. Publications from 2004 to the present were reviewed with an emphasis on literature since 2014.

sec.title: Recent Findings
sec.p: Sulfonylureas, often taken at high doses, have now been utilized effectively in KCNJ11 patients for over 10 years. Mild-moderate hypoglycemia can occur, but in two studies with a combined 975 patient-years on sulfonylureas, no severe hypoglycemic events were reported. Improvements in neurodevelopment and motor function after transition to sulfonylureas continue to be described.

sec.title: Summary
sec.p: Sulfonylureas continue to be an effective, sustainable, and safe treatment for KCNJ11-related diabetes. Ongoing follow-up of patients in research registries will allow for deeper understanding of the facilitators and barriers to long-term sustainability. Further understanding of the effect of sulfonylurea on long-term neurodevelopmental outcomes, and the potential for adjunctive therapies, is needed.
